 The problem is that you cannot "shape" a nuclear detonation. they are always symmetrical and the initial explosion is always a perfect sphere (laws of physics and all that). So what you would have to settle for is a focused explosion. Focused explosions use a reflector of some kind to focus the energy of the explosion in a certain direction.
 
 So, all you really need is to come up with some kind of material that will not be vaporized despite the fact that you would have to place it within inches of a nuclear detonation. Then you have to make it light enough to be carried by airplane. So far there is no material known to man that can do it, but maybe you and JP could whip something up over the weekend and change the laws of physics as we know them (since as we currently understand things, it would be impossible for such a light material to survive). 
 
 Looking at projected time lines for various scientific advancements, we will almost certainly develop the the technology to teleport the bombs into the bunkers LONG before we develop the materials and technology to shoot them or drop them there. 
 
 When I was in the military there were certain situations that we referred to as MWR situations....Man With Rifle. Those were the situations where no amount of technical gee wizadry, no cruise missile, no matter how accurate, and no number of bombing sorties could solve the problem. Typically it was used in reference to hostage situations or covert infiltrations, but it was also applied to situations like the Iranian bunker situation. There is no technology that is going to solve the problem. No number of Apaches or B-2 bombers is going to solve it. If we want to take those bunkers, we have to get old school....in this case back to the middle ages when siege warfare was the norm. 
 
 From what I remember from briefings, the Iranian bunker complex is the most heavily fortified in the world. There are over 300 known entrances (known by us) and probably that many that we do not know about. Over half of the complex is designed to withstand repeated, full yield nuclear detonations. Their tunneling equipment is stored inside the complex in a number of different locations which ensures that they can always create new entrances or clear collapsed sections without outside aid. They carry enough food, fuel, water, and supplies to keep 150,000 combat troops 100% combat effective for 3 years. 
 
 Taking those bunkers would be the ultimate game of whack a mole. You set up outside as many entrances as you can, the enemy pops out of one that you did not cover either because you did not have a million troops at your disposal, or because it pops out in ackbars basement and you didn't know about it. They kill a bunch of your troops, then retreat back into the bunker. They pop out somewhere else, kill some more, pop back in. All the while your supply lines are being harassed, your armor is under MAJOR pressure, and your helicopters cannot operate because unlike the 40 yr old shoulder fired AA weapons that were only partly sucessful in Iraq, the Iranians have nice new shoulder fired AA weapons that can take down our helicopters just fine. Also, at the same time, the US economy is tanking because the Iranains are popping silkworms like they are going to expire next week and are sinking anything and everything that floats in the persian gulf. 
 
 Not a good scenario.
